flow.context: Rachael Sale is a Property Manager / Reservationist at Beachfront Only Vacation Rentals — 85+ oceanfront-only STR properties in Oceanside, Carlsbad, and Encinitas (North County San Diego). She likely coordinates unit readiness between cleaners and turnover specialists and handles guest-reported issues day-to-day. The company already has dedicated turnover specialists inspecting after every stay, uses Track as their PMS, UpKeep for maintenance, and runs tight same-day turns (10AM out / 4PM in) across a dense oceanfront portfolio under increasing Oceanside STR permit caps. Key people above her: Peter Rodriguez (Maintenance & Ops Manager), Iryna Djomins (Housekeeping Manager), David Fischbach (CEO/Owner). No direct personal connection to Sam — lead with working with other North County San Diego coastal property managers.

gatekeeper_slide_by.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_slide_by.say: Hey — could you get me over to Rachael? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_slide_by.note: Say it like you know her. Casual. Don't volunteer anything else unless asked. If Rachael answers directly or you're told you ARE speaking to her, skip straight to opener.

branches.label: You ARE Rachael / she answers directly

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — GIVE CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers in the North County area. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain RapidEye. Just give enough to sound like someone she'd want to talk to.

branches.label: Still pushing back / wants more detail

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally — we help a couple property management companies with their turnover inspection workflows. I sent her a note. Would you mind just giving her a heads up that Sam Parks called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Three doses given. If still blocked, get a callback time or ask for voicemail. Don't argue.

gatekeeper_not_available.label: GATEKEEPER — NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_not_available.say: No worries at all. When's usually a good time to catch her? I'll try back then.
gatekeeper_not_available.note: Get a specific time or day. Write it down. If they offer voicemail, take it but still ask for a callback window.

branches.label: They give a time / offer voicemail
"I can transfer you to someone else"

gatekeeper_redirect.label: GATEKEEPER — REDIRECTED TO SOMEONE ELSE
gatekeeper_redirect.say: Sure — who would that be? That'd be great.
gatekeeper_redirect.note: If they route you to Peter Rodriguez (Maintenance & Ops) or Iryna Djomins (Housekeeping), that's actually a BETTER contact. Take the redirect eagerly and adjust your opener for that person.

gatekeeper_dead_end.label: GATEKEEPER — DEAD END
gatekeeper_dead_end.say: Appreciate your help — I'll try back. Thanks!
gatekeeper_dead_end.note: Log callback time. Note who you spoke with and any names mentioned. Try again at the suggested time.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Rachael — I work with a few property managers in the North County San Diego coastal market. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Casual. Feet up on the desk energy. Don't rush the question — let it hang. If you got redirected to someone other than Rachael, swap the name and adjust.

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES — EXPLORE
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — normally we'd be working with someone in your role. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, use it to bridge into discovery. If she's vague or doesn't really remember, transition into the pain trigger naturally.

branches.label: She shares what she heard / is curious

heard_no.label: HEARD NO — TRANSITION TO PAIN
heard_no.say: Oh — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well, the reason I'm calling — I was talking to another property manager who runs a pretty similar setup to Beachfront Only. About 80 oceanfront units, tight same-day turns. She was telling me that even with people checking every unit after cleaning, things were still slipping through. Guest checks in, finds a broken towel rack or a missing set of dishes, and now it's a scramble and a bad review. She was spending hours on photos her team was already taking, but nobody actually had time to go through them all before the next guest walked in.
heard_no.note: This is the pain trigger. Deliver it like you're telling a story, not reading a pitch. PAUSE after this. Let her react. Do NOT jump to the solution — let the silence do the work.

branches.label: "We already have a process for that"
"I'm not really the person for this"

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe same time?
bad_timing.note: Suggest a specific day. Lock in the callback. Don't pitch anything right now.

branches.label: She gives a time / agrees to callback
"Just tell me what it's about real quick"

reschedule_callback.label: RESCHEDULE — LOCK IT IN
reschedule_callback.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Rachael.
reschedule_callback.note: Write down the exact day and time. Set a reminder. When you call back, open with: 'Hey Rachael, Sam Parks — you told me to try you back today.'

whats_this_about.label: WHAT'S THIS ABOUT — PERMISSION FALLBACK
whats_this_about.say: Yeah, totally fair — it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
whats_this_about.note: Disarm with honesty. The self-deprecation lowers her guard. If she says yes, go straight into the pain trigger. If no, split the objection.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it more that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Split it into two options. Most people will clarify, which cracks the door back open. Listen carefully to which one she picks.

warm_response.label: SHE'S WARM — STOP PITCHING, START ASKING
warm_response.say: Yeah — I figured that might sound familiar. So what does that look like for you guys right now? I know Beachfront Only has turnover specialists checking after every clean — are you involved in that workflow, or is that more on Peter's side?
warm_response.note: You just name-dropped Peter Rodriguez (Maintenance & Ops Manager). This shows you did your homework. Listen for whether she owns this process or routes you elsewhere. If she asks how you know Peter, stay casual.

knowledge_explain.label: EXPLAIN HOW YOU KNOW THEIR OPS
knowledge_explain.say: Oh — I was just doing some homework before calling. Saw his name come up as your Maintenance and Ops lead. Honestly, the reason your company stood out to me is you guys already have that inspection step built in after every clean — most companies don't even bother. I'm curious what that actually looks like day-to-day for you.
knowledge_explain.note: Compliment their process. Then pivot right back to discovery questions. Don't let this become a tangent about your research methods.

branches.label: She opens up about the process

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — CURRENT PROCESS
discovery_process.say: Walk me through it — when a guest checks out at 10 AM and the next one's coming at 4, what happens between the clean and the turnover specialist signing off? Are they taking photos, or is it more of a visual walkthrough?
discovery_process.note: You know their check-in/out times — use that specificity. Listen for: are photos taken? What tool? Who reviews? What falls through the cracks? How long does the inspection take per unit?

branches.label: They take photos (in Track, UpKeep, or manually)
She's not sure / vague on details

discovery_photo_workflow.label: DISCOVERY — PHOTO WORKFLOW
discovery_photo_workflow.say: Got it — so the photos are getting taken. Here's what I'm curious about: is anyone actually reviewing all of those photos before the next guest checks in? Or is it more of a 'take them for the record' situation?
discovery_photo_workflow.note: This is the money question. Almost nobody reviews all photos in real time between turns. If she admits nobody does, you have your opening. If she says they do, ask how long it takes and what still slips through.

branches.label: "Nobody really reviews them all" / admits gap

discovery_no_photos.label: DISCOVERY — NO STRUCTURED PHOTO WORKFLOW
discovery_no_photos.say: Makes sense. So when something does get missed — like a guest finds damage or something's off — how does that usually surface? Is it guest complaints coming in, or does the specialist catch most of it on the walkthrough?
discovery_no_photos.note: Probe for where pain shows up. If issues surface via guest complaints, that's a clear pain point. If specialists catch most things, ask what they miss and how long each inspection takes.

branches.label: She opens up about specific problems

discovery_probe_deeper.label: DISCOVERY — PROBE DEEPER
discovery_probe_deeper.say: No worries — I know it's a lot of moving pieces. Let me ask it this way: when a guest complains about something that should've been caught before check-in, where does that land? Does that come to you, or does that go to the maintenance team?
discovery_probe_deeper.note: Figure out her role in the escalation chain. If complaints land on her desk, she feels this pain personally. If they go to maintenance, she'll likely route you to Peter — which is still a win.

branches.label: "That comes to me" / she owns it

discovery_what_slips.label: DISCOVERY — WHAT STILL SLIPS THROUGH
discovery_what_slips.say: That's solid — honestly better than most operators I talk to. What's the stuff that still gets through? Is it more cosmetic things — staging off, missing items — or is it actual damage that gets missed?
discovery_what_slips.note: Even the best process has gaps. Let her name them. Whatever she says becomes your anchor when you present the solution. If she says 'honestly not much,' pivot to the regulatory angle.

regulatory_angle.label: REGULATORY PRESSURE ANGLE
regulatory_angle.say: That's great you've got it buttoned up. I know Oceanside just capped non-hosted STR permits — only about 25 slots left under that cap. With that kind of scrutiny, I'd imagine every guest complaint or neighbor issue carries more weight now than it did a couple years ago. Is that something you guys are feeling at all?
regulatory_angle.note: Backup hook. Regulatory pressure means even small missed issues can have outsized consequences — permit risk, neighbor complaints, city attention. If she engages, bridge to: 'That's exactly why automated catch matters — it's not just reviews, it's protecting your permits.'

solution_bridge.label: SOLUTION — ONE SENTENCE
solution_bridge.say: So here's the short version — we built a tool that plugs into the photos and videos your team's already capturing during turnovers and automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues. It works with Track, which I think you guys are on. No workflow change — your people keep doing what they're doing, but now every photo actually gets reviewed before the next guest walks in.
solution_bridge.note: One breath. Don't oversell. You mentioned Track on purpose — shows you know their stack. Now go straight to the CTA. Don't wait for permission to pitch more.

branches.label: "I'd need to run this by someone"

cta_meeting.label: CTA — ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a look at it when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue? Even just 15 minutes — I can show you what it actually catches on real turnover photos. Worst case, you see how other PM companies in the coastal market are handling this and steal some ideas.
cta_meeting.note: Low-friction. Position the meeting as valuable even if they never buy. If she says yes, go straight to booking a time. Don't let it float.

branches.label: "I'd need to involve Peter / my manager"

handle_pricing.label: HANDLE PRICING QUESTION
handle_pricing.say: Honestly, it depends on unit count and how you're set up — I don't want to throw out a number that doesn't mean anything. That's actually part of why a quick call makes sense. Would you be open to 15 minutes so I can show you what it does and give you a real number based on your setup?
handle_pricing.note: Never quote price on a cold call. Use the pricing question as a reason TO meet. If she pushes hard, offer to include ballpark ranges in a follow-up email.

branches.label: "Just send me an email with pricing"

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that this just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise her. Then split the objection. Most people will say 'I just hate cold calls' which reopens the door. If she says it's not a priority, dig into what IS their priority.

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 85-plus oceanfront properties you'd have to have something locked in. Just out of curiosity — is it more that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: They DO have a real process — turnover specialists inspect every unit. Validate it. The split separates 'happy' from 'change-averse.' If it's the latter, the no-disruption angle is your best card.

branches.label: "Switching would be a pain" / change fatigue

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new. Just so no one bugs you again — is it that budget for this kind of thing is completely off the table, or is it more that anything you try to buy has to go through a gauntlet to get approved?
objection_no_budget.note: Split budget into 'no money at all' vs 'painful approval process.' If it's the latter, offer the test drive framing. If everything goes through ownership, that's a referral opportunity to David or Adele Fischbach.

objection_not_my_call.label: OBJECTION — NOT MY DECISION
objection_not_my_call.say: Totally fair. Who on your team usually owns the inspection and turnover workflow? Is that more Peter on the maintenance side, or does it sit somewhere else?
objection_not_my_call.note: You already know Peter Rodriguez runs Maintenance & Ops and Iryna Djomins runs Housekeeping. If she names either, confirm and ask for an intro. If she names ownership (David, Adele, Adam Fischbach), adjust accordingly. Any name is a win.

branches.label: "That's more of a David / ownership decision"

referral_to_peter.label: REFERRAL — ROUTE TO PETER RODRIGUEZ
referral_to_peter.say: Peter Rodriguez, right? He runs your maintenance and operations. Would you be open to connecting me with him? I can put something tailored together so it actually lands — not just a generic cold pitch. Or if it's easier, I could just mention you pointed me his way.
referral_to_peter.note: Peter is the #1 target contact at this company. If she'll intro you or give his direct line, that's gold. When you call Peter, open with: 'Rachael Sale mentioned you'd be the right person to talk to about this.'

branches.label: She'll intro or give his contact info
"Just call the main line and ask for him"
"I'll pass your info along to him"

referral_to_iryna.label: REFERRAL — ROUTE TO IRYNA DJOMINS
referral_to_iryna.say: Got it — Iryna on the housekeeping side? That makes sense since the turnover photos would come from her team. Would you mind connecting me, or should I just reach out to her directly?
referral_to_iryna.note: Iryna Djomins is the Housekeeping Manager. Her team likely generates the photos. Great secondary contact. Get an intro if possible.

branches.label: She'll intro or give contact info
"Just call the office and ask for her"

referral_to_ownership.label: REFERRAL — ROUTE TO OWNERSHIP
referral_to_ownership.say: Makes sense — that'd be David Fischbach, right? Would you be open to connecting me, or is there a better way to get in front of him? If I can get the right channel, I'll put something specific together so it doesn't just land in a pile.
referral_to_ownership.note: David Fischbach is CEO. Adele Fischbach is listed as Manager/Principal on BBB. Adam Fischbach is also an owner. If she names any of them, take it. If she resists, ask if there's a manager between her and ownership who handles vendor decisions.

branches.label: "I don't really know the best way"

referral_general.label: REFERRAL — GENERAL ASK
referral_general.say: No worries. If you had to guess — who's the person that would care most about making turnover inspections faster and catching stuff before guests find it? I just want to make sure I'm reaching the right person.
referral_general.note: Let her think. Don't fill the silence. Any name is a win. If she genuinely doesn't know, ask if there's an operations manager or ops director.

referral_involve_others.label: REFERRAL — INVOLVE OTHERS IN MEETING
referral_involve_others.say: Totally — would it make sense to loop them into a quick call? I'm happy to set up 15 minutes where you and whoever needs to be there can just see it together. That way you're not stuck playing telephone with my pitch.
referral_involve_others.note: Try to get a joint meeting. One meeting with Rachael + Peter or Rachael + David is better than two separate cold calls. If she names who should be there, lock in the meeting.

branches.label: "Just send me something and I'll forward it"

recovery_after_split.label: RECOVERY — THEY HATE COLD CALLS
recovery_after_split.say: Ha — fair enough, I don't love making them either. Look, I'll be quick: we built something that automatically reviews turnover photos so your team doesn't have to eyeball every single one. Works with Track. Would you be open to 15 minutes this week just to see if it's even relevant? If it's not, I'll leave you alone for good.
recovery_after_split.note: She opened the door by admitting it's the cold call she hates, not the topic. Give her one clean shot at the value prop and CTA. Keep it tight.

recovery_priority.label: RECOVERY — NOT A PRIORITY
recovery_priority.say: Totally fair. What's the biggest thing on your plate right now heading into the busy season? I ask because a lot of the coastal PM companies I talk to are all dealing with the same handful of things — just curious where you guys are at.
recovery_priority.note: Shift to open-ended discovery. If she names anything ops-related — staffing, turnover speed, guest complaints, growth — bridge back to how RapidEye helps. If it's truly unrelated, plant a seed and exit gracefully.

recovery_working_fine.label: RECOVERY — PROCESS IS WORKING FINE
recovery_working_fine.say: That's honestly great — you guys are ahead of most companies I talk to. Most don't even have a dedicated inspection step after cleaning. Here's what I've seen though: even the best turnover specialists can only be in one unit at a time. When you've got eight properties turning over on the same Saturday and the next guest is checking in at four, something's gonna get missed just by physics. Would you be open to seeing how a couple companies in a similar spot are using AI to back up their existing team — not replace them?
recovery_working_fine.note: Don't argue with 'it's working.' Compliment it genuinely. Then introduce scale as the real constraint — 85+ units, simultaneous turns, tight windows. The AI-as-backup framing is non-threatening to their existing process.

recovery_no_change_needed.label: RECOVERY — CHANGE FATIGUE
recovery_no_change_needed.say: Totally — and honestly that's the best part. There's zero workflow change. Your cleaners and turnover specialists keep doing exactly what they're already doing. We just plug into the photos that are already being taken in Track and flag anything that needs attention before the next guest walks in. Nobody learns a new app, nobody changes their routine. Would you be open to seeing how it works? Fifteen minutes, tops.
recovery_no_change_needed.note: The no-disruption angle is your strongest card when they're change-averse. They already take photos; they already inspect; RapidEye just adds an automated review layer on top.

recovery_test_drive.label: RECOVERY — TEST DRIVE FRAMING
recovery_test_drive.say: Totally respect that. You're probably not buying anything right now, and that's fine. But when budget does open up or the timing's right, the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look — not to buy, just so you know what's out there? Worst case, you see what other coastal PM companies are doing with their turnover workflows and you steal some ideas. We part as friends.
recovery_test_drive.note: Remove all buying pressure. Position the meeting as intelligence-gathering, not a sales call. This is the 'sell the test drive' play.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — does Tuesday or Thursday work better for you? I can do morning or afternoon.
book_meeting.note: Give two options. Lock in the day and time NOW while she's on the phone. Don't say 'I'll send you a link to schedule' — get the verbal commitment first, then send the invite.

branches.label: "Let me check my calendar and get back to you"

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN DOWN THE MEETING
pin_down_meeting.say: For sure — how about I shoot you an invite for Thursday at 11 and you can move it if that doesn't work? What's the best email — rachael at beachfrontonly dot com?
pin_down_meeting.note: Don't let it float. Suggest a concrete time and send a real invite. Getting her email also confirms your contact info. A sent invite is 5x more likely to happen than 'I'll get back to you.'

branches.label: She confirms email / agrees to invite

confirm_meeting.label: CONFIRM & CLOSE
confirm_meeting.say: Perfect — sending that over right now. And if anyone else on your team should be on the call — like Peter on the ops side or whoever handles turnovers day-to-day — feel free to loop them in. Really appreciate you taking my call, Rachael.
confirm_meeting.note: STOP SELLING. The meeting is booked. Mention Peter casually to plant the seed for a multi-stakeholder meeting. Send the calendar invite within 5 minutes of hanging up. Add her to your follow-up sequence for a reminder the day before.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it doesn't just sit in your inbox as another generic pitch? Like, are you more curious about how it works technically, or what it actually catches on real turnovers?
send_email.note: Don't just say 'sure' and hang up — that email will die in their inbox. Ask what matters to THEM so the email is tailored. Then confirm her email address and include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email.

branches.label: She tells you what to include

send_email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL DETAILS
send_email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. Best email is rachael at beachfrontonly dot com? And I'll throw a couple time options in there in case you want to hop on a quick call after you look it over. Appreciate your time, Rachael.
send_email_confirm.note: Confirm the email address. In the email: include exactly what she asked for, a clear CTA with two specific time options, and a one-liner about what other similar-sized coastal PM companies are seeing. Follow up in 2-3 business days if no response.

end_with_referral.label: END — GOT A REFERRAL
end_with_referral.say: That's super helpful — I'll reach out to them directly and mention you pointed me their way. Really appreciate it, Rachael.
end_with_referral.note: You got a name. That's a win. When calling the referral, open with: 'Rachael Sale mentioned you'd be the right person to talk to about this.' Log the referral name immediately.

end_graceful.label: END — GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Rachael.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Log the outcome and her objection. She's still a door to Peter Rodriguez, Iryna Djomins, or David Fischbach later. Note her name and this conversation for future outreach.
